faq.section_subtitle: Practical answers about our mobile service — so you know exactly what to expect
faq.cta_subtitle: We reply within 30 minutes on average.

items.question: Do I need to provide a power outlet or water supply?
items.answer: No — we are 100% self-sufficient. We bring our own generator, professional-grade polishing machines, and water supply. All you need to provide is a parking spot or marina berth access.

items.question: How much clear space do you need around the car or boat?
items.answer: For a car: approximately 1 metre of clear space on each working side is ideal — a standard parking bay is sufficient. For yacht work, we operate directly at your marina berth with no haulout required.

items.question: What happens if it rains or weather conditions are poor?
items.answer: Glass and acrylic jobs can proceed in light rain. Paint correction and ceramic coating require dry conditions. We check the forecast in advance — if conditions are unsuitable, we reschedule at no charge and no inconvenience to you.

items.question: Do I need to be present during the entire service?
items.answer: Not at all. Most clients leave their car or boat and get on with their day. Just leave us access to the vehicle and a contact number. We send you a photo report when the job is complete.

items.question: What is your satisfaction guarantee?
items.answer: Simple: if you are not satisfied with the result, we come back and redo it at zero extra cost. Premium ceramic packages include a 12-month coating protection warranty. The price you approve is always the price you pay — no surprises.

academy.headline: Academy: Engineering Excellence
academy.intro: Every restoration we perform is rooted in material science, not guesswork. This section is where we share the engineering principles behind our work — so you understand exactly why our results are different.
bullets: Equipment selection logic — why we use specific machines, pads and compounds for each surface type
The physics behind paint decontamination — iron fallout, tar, and bonded mineral deposits
Correction mechanics — how abrasive particles interact with clear coat at a microscopic level
Real case breakdowns — step-by-step documentation of complex restorations
academy.closing: Articles are released as they're written. Subscribe-free — just bookmark this page and check back.

articles.title: Equipment Selection Protocols
articles.excerpt: Why we choose specific rotary and DA polishers, backing plates, and pad compounds for each job — and how the wrong choice can damage a surface permanently.

articles.title: The Physics of Decontamination
articles.excerpt: Iron fallout, tar, tree sap, bonded mineral deposits — the science of why clay bars work and when chemical decontamination is the only safe option.

articles.title: The Mechanics of Correction
articles.excerpt: How wool pads cut differently from foam, why diminishing abrasives behave the way they do, and the engineering behind a flawless final finish.

equipment_selection.title: Choosing Your Weapon: Rotary vs. Dual Action
equipment_selection.description: Process Physics: Why 99% of the Result Depends on Tool Selection. Learn to distinguish the handling of a "go-kart" from the behavior of a "semi-truck," and understand why a low center of gravity is the foundation of professional paint correction.
equipment_selection.intro: In our lab, we follow a clear protocol: the first pass — the one that removes 99% of all scratches — is most effectively done with a rotary polisher. The dual action machine, by contrast, is a tool for final surface stabilization.

sections.title: Rotary Polisher: Power and Control
paragraphs: The rotary is the foundation of deep correction. When selecting a machine, we focus on three critical parameters:
key_params: Stability under load — no "drop-off" (loss of RPM) under pressure at low speeds.
Low center of gravity — the shorter the spindle (shaft), the closer the tool sits to the surface, and the greater the control over the process.
Power modulation — the ability to precisely control RPM for safe operation on curves and body lines.

analogy.title: RestoreLab engineering analogy
analogy.text: Working with a tool that has a high or shifted center of gravity is like driving a tall semi-truck — it turns, but it will never have the precision of a go-kart. A professional rotary polisher (for example, the Makita 9237CB) is a go-kart: low-slung, predictable, and extremely efficient.

sections.conclusion: Our lab's choice is the Makita 9237CB. It delivers ideal handling thanks to its low center of gravity and stability at lower speed settings.

sections.title: Dual Action: The Finishing Scalpel
paragraphs: Once the major defects have been removed with the rotary, the finishing stage begins. The backing plate of a dual action polisher performs two types of motion at once: rotational and oscillating. This makes it possible to achieve a perfectly clean surface without holograms.
